topics.title: Design craft as software differentiation
topics.summary: Dylan argues the era of “good enough” is over and that winning software teams differentiate through design quality and craft.

topics.title: Early founder lessons: ship faster, reach market
topics.summary: Dylan shares Figma’s long path to revenue and advises founders to get to market faster rather than over-polishing before launch.

topics.title: Counterintuitive bet: making FigJam fun
topics.summary: A month before launch, the team realized FigJam lacked “soul” and chose fun as the differentiator—leading to defining features like Cursor Chat and a stronger multi-product muscle.

topics.title: AI prototyping shifts PM-designer collaboration
topics.summary: They discuss how AI prototyping (Figma Make) changes workflows: PMs can prototype directly, freeing designers to go deeper while broadening early exploration.

topics.title: AI and jobs: productivity, hiring, uncertainty
topics.summary: Dylan notes productivity gains from models but says it hasn’t reduced engineering hiring; outcomes depend on how AI capabilities and orgs evolve.

topics.title: Introduction and sponsor: episode setup and Stripe
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Dylan and the episode topics, then transitions into a Stripe sponsor read highlighting enterprise payments, billing, and checkout.

topics.title: Adobe deal collapse and accelerating afterward
topics.summary: Dylan recounts the regulatory-driven failure of the Adobe acquisition and explains how Figma kept momentum, then pushed forward with launches like Dev Mode.

topics.title: Keeping morale: communication and the “Detach” program
topics.summary: Dylan details frequent updates during the deal process and a post-deal reset offering voluntary severance (“Detach”) to ensure the remaining team was fully bought in.

topics.title: Maintaining startup speed at 13 years
topics.summary: They cover how Figma sustains pace: choosing motivating problems, challenging padded timelines, staying flatter, managing assumptions, and balancing tech debt.

topics.title: Culture: maker energy and Make-a-Week hackathons
topics.summary: Dylan explains Figma’s culture as people-first and maker-driven, reinforced by rituals like Make-a-Week that generate major product bets (e.g., Slides).

topics.title: Competitive kindness and leadership evolution
topics.summary: Dylan reflects on being competitive with good sportsmanship, then describes how he’s grown as a leader—especially around unpacking context and creating clarity.

topics.title: Learning from others and two-way mentorship
topics.summary: They discuss how Dylan learns from execs and teammates, challenging the idea that CEOs should only mentor—highlighting mutual learning and debate as a growth engine.

topics.title: Product line expansion: follow the workflow, not TAM
topics.summary: Dylan outlines Figma’s expansion logic across the idea-to-shipping workflow (Slides, FigJam, Dev Mode/MCP, Draw, Buzz, Sites, Make) and argues TAM is often misleading because markets can expand as expectations shift.

topics.title: Time-to-value and removing adoption blockers
topics.summary: Dylan explains optimizing “time to value” and why fixing blockers can move activation/retention metrics dramatically, while still balancing table-stakes work with a compelling vision.

topics.title: Sponsor break and Figma Make overview
topics.summary: A brief Stripe sponsor read transitions into an explanation of Figma Make: prompting into prototypes and apps, plus the importance of round-tripping between Make and Figma Design for refinement.

topics.title: Figma Make use cases: prototyping first, apps next
topics.summary: They discuss emerging AI-building use cases (team prototypes, internal tools, production apps), with Dylan emphasizing prototyping as the primary focus while improving paths to shippable, design-system-consistent outputs.
